newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugo govt services blamed for 6.6 pct inflation.
newsitem.headline: Yugo govt services blamed for 6.6 pct inflation.

text.p: A group of leading Yugoslav economists on Thursday blamed a huge hike in the price of government services for dragging July's inflation to what they described as an alarming rate of 6.6 percent.
According to the Statistics Office, government services rose an average of 10.4 percent in July, helping to blow out the previous month's inflation of 3.3 percent.
"Therefore we suggest that the government abstain from any further price increases in services," said Miroljub Labus, a chief economist at the Belgrade-based Economic Institute.
According to the Institute, the price of services, including those controlled by the state, climbed 114.2 percent from January to July.
The same seven month period shows consumer prices rising by 28 percent and industrial goods by 26.7 percent. No separate figures were available for state-supplied services.

"(Monthly) inflation must not enter double digits. The government must try to keep the dinar exchange rate stable and retain both fiscal and monetary stability," said Jurij Bajec, another member of the Institute and a professor at the Belgrade School of Economics.
Both Labus and Bajec said the government should stick to its current monetary and fiscal policies without sacrificing stability of the country's economy.

The two economists said provided there were no unforseen catastrophies, the government could reign in August's inflation to 3 percent by controling the cost of services. -- Gordana Filipovic, Belgrade newsroom, +381 11 222 4254
